monogr.author: Lydgate, John

monogr.title: John Lydgate's Dance of Death and Related Works

projectDesc.p: The Middle English Texts Series offers a diverse and representative array of literary texts that medieval readers in the present-day British Isles would have encountered between the twelfth and sixteenth centuries. It is committed to making available both affordable print and open access editions to scholars, teachers, and students of the Western Middle Ages. In its digital publications, the series prioritizes a user-friendly interface and viewing options, multiple downloadable formats, enhanced searchability and filtering, and accessibility to the widest possible range of users.

editorialDecl.p: METS takes as its mission the creation of affordable editions that would pass scrutiny from the most demanding expert, yet would prove comprehensible, and even enticing, to someone who had never read Middle English before. This agenda dictates that METS publications offer not a critical edition reflecting all surviving manuscripts, and certainly not a diplomatic edition, but a best-text edition, informed by the notes and apparatus of earlier editions (where these exist), and by substantive variants from other manuscript witnesses. Transcriptions of Middle English texts are lightly modernized to ensure a smooth reading experience, while non-English texts preserve both the original language and a modern English translation in facing-page format. Each edition offers expert assistance with language and lexicon, providing glosses alongside the text(s), textual and explanatory notes, elucidation of unfamiliar contexts and traditions, and thematic and interpretive possibilities. All editions feature general introductions that set the edited text within its own time, place, and traditions, and link it to ancestor, congener, and successor materials. All publications contain comprehensive, current bibliographies of pertinent scholarship and criticism. House style is adapted from the Chicago Manual of Style.

correction.p: This text may include corrections made after the original edition went to press in order to correct errors and improve glosses. For a full list of editorial and typographical corrections made to this edition, please view its correction log on Github: https://github.com/mets-editions/cook-lydgate/blob/main/cook-lydgate-export-corrections-log.docx

p.l: A dolfull daunce and song of death
Intituled: the shakeing of the sheetes

lg.l: Canne yea dance the shakinge of the sheetes,N
A daunce that everie manT most dooe?
Can yea trime it up with daintie sweetes,
And everie thinge thatT longsG there too?belongs
Make readie then your winding sheete,N
And see how yea canne besturre youre feete,
For Death is the man that all must meete.
Bringe away the beggar and the king,
And everie man in his degree;
Bring away bothT ould and yongest thinge;
Come all to Death and follow me —
The courtier with his loftie lookes,
The lawierG with his learned bookes,lawyer
AndT the banker with his beating hookes.N T
Marchantes that make yourT martG in France,business (market)
In Italie, and all about,
Know you not that you and I must daunce,
With both our heelesT wrapt in a clout?Ga [burial] cloth
What meane you to make your houses gay
And I must take the tenant away,
And digge for your sakes the clods of clay?G(i.e., a grave)
Thinke onT the solempe sysesG last,solemn assizes
How sodenlieG in OxfordshireN suddenly
I came and made the judges agast,T
And justices that did appear,
And tooke both Bell and Baram away,N
And manie a worthie man that day,
And all their bodies brought to clay.
Thinke youT I dare not come in scooles,T Gschools
Where all the cunninge clarkesG be most?clerics
Take not I awayT both wise and fooles?
And am not I in everie coast?
Assure youreselves noe creature can
Make Death afraid of any man,
Or know my comminge where or when.
And you that are busie-headedT G foolesbusy-headed (distracted)
To brawleG for everieT peltingeN G straw,brawl worthless
Know yea not that I have readie tooles
To cut awayT youre craftie law?
And you that foolishlyT buy and sell,
And thinke you make your market well,
Must daunce with Death wheresoever you dwell.
Where be they that make their leases stronge,
And joyne about them land to land?
Doe yea acountT G to live soe longe,expect
To have all the worldT come to your hand?
Noe, foolish nowell,G for all thy penceGne’er-do-well money
This night thy soule must sure goe henceT —
Then whoe shall toile for thy defence?
And you that leane on your ladies lappes,
And lay your heades upon her knee,T
Doe you thinke to playT with bewties pappes,Gbeauties’ breasts
And not to come and daunce with me?
Noe, faith,T fair laddesT and ladies all,
I’le make you come when I do call,
And find you a pipe to dance withall.
PrydG must have a prittieG sheete, I see,Pride pretty
For properly he learnesT to daunce,
Come away, my wanton wench to me
As gallantlie as your eye dothT glance;
And all good fellowes that swashG and flashT swagger
In reds and yellows of revellG dash,revelry
I warrant you neede not be soe rash.
For I cane quicklie coole you all,
How hot or stout soever you be,
Both high and lowe, both great and small,
I nought doe feare your highe degree.
The ladieT faire, the beldamT ould,Gold grandmother
The champion stout, the souldier bould,
Must all with me to erthie mould.Gsoil
Take time therefore while it is lent,
Prepare youreselvesT with me to daunce,
Forget mee not, your lives lament —
I come oft-times by sodenG chance.sudden
Be readie therefore, watch and pray
That when my minstrell pypes his playT
Yea may to heaven daunce readie way.T
